They nodded, satisfied. We moved on.

title: The Accidental Production

contents:
I was browsing LinkedIn and a few other platforms, looking for sysadmin or system engineer positions. Nothing. Or almost nothing.
It turns out that ‚ÄúSystem Administrator‚Äù is apparently too old-school now. The title seems to have quietly disappeared, replaced by an explosion of new ones: DevOps Engineer, Cloud Engineer, Platform Engineer, Site Reliability Engineer, Cloud Architect… and even Operations Ninja.
All these roles sound different, yet when you read the job descriptions, they all seem to mean the same thing. Run servers, automate stuff, fix things, you know, the usual.
It‚Äôs like someone fed an AI the phrase “System Administrator” and asked it to generate 50 trendier versions. üòÖ
In the end, whether you call it DevOps, SRE, or “Cloud-Native Synergy Architect”, the mission hasn‚Äôt changed: keep the systems alive and the lights on.
Disclaimer: I obviously know that the role of a system administrator has evolved and specialized into many new fields over time: DevOps, SRE, Platform Engineering and beyond. The title generator joke was too good to resist. üòÑ

Every IT team has that one server. The one sitting in the corner of the rack with a dusty case, a yellowed label that says ‚ÄúDO NOT TOUCH‚Äù, and an aura of mystery.
This one ran on RHEL 3. When it was first installed, I was around 10 or 12 years old. It had lived through hardware migrations, OS updates, and entire generations of sysadmins: or rather, survived them.
Nobody really knew who had set it up. Nobody wanted to be the one to reboot it. At some point, it was even virtualized, like a digital relic carefully preserved in amber.
Its uptime was legendary. Every time someone mentioned replacing it, there was always a quiet “let‚Äôs not risk it.” You could almost feel the fear of breaking the ancient spell that kept it running.
It‚Äôs the kind of server you respect more than you understand. Because sometimes, in IT, stability doesn‚Äôt come from modernization. It comes from superstition. üòÖ

contents:
This story is inspired by something very real: the invisible work of system administrators.
Their job isn‚Äôt to ship new features or flashy updates, it‚Äôs to make sure that everything just works. Servers stay up, backups run, emails flow, and systems stay secure. Most of it happens quietly, behind the scenes, where no one really notices… until something breaks.
Unfortunately, some managers don‚Äôt see that. When they don‚Äôt understand the technical side, they think “nothing‚Äôs happening.” Micromanagement takes over, trust disappears, and appreciation fades. And eventually, the sysadmins decide to leave. Because, let‚Äôs be honest, there‚Äôs no shortage of work for skilled people elsewhere.
Then what happens next? Well… that‚Äôs where my imagination begins. üòÖ Servers crashing, chaos in the office, smoke in the datacenter, the whole empire crumbling without its silent guardians.
It‚Äôs funny in the comic, but painfully real in many places. System administrators keep the digital world running, often without thanks, until the moment they‚Äôre gone.
Maybe it’s time we appreciate uptime before it disappears.

contents:
A major project had just been approved: a collaboration between several partners, with a generous budget to set up new infrastructure. One partner was in charge of purchasing the servers and hosting them in their datacenter. The plan was simple: coordinate with everyone, agree on the specifications, and move forward together.
Well… that last part didn‚Äôt happen.
Without consulting anyone, the partner decided to order high-end IBM proprietary Big Data servers, proudly announcing the purchase once it was too late to change anything. üí∏
The result? The machines looked impressive, cost a fortune… but were completely unusable for the project.
We did, however, get a nice guided tour of the datacenter, with big shiny racks labeled ‚ÄúFunded by the project‚Äù. Beautiful to look at, completely useless in practice.
In the end, the partner had to provide a new infrastructure at their own expense, and the project finally moved forward… just a few months late.
Sometimes, “coordination” really is the most valuable hardware you can invest in. üòÖ

contents:
It started as a new and exciting mission. The client needed help setting up proper CI/CD pipelines and introducing DevOps best practices. Everything sounded great.
Then came the small detail that hadn‚Äôt been mentioned during the initial discussions.
‚ÄúOh, by the way, our application runs on Windows‚Ä¶ and we use Windows containers.‚Äù
I froze for a second. Windows‚Ä¶ containers? I didn‚Äôt even know those existed before that project.
I‚Äôd always worked with Linux. For me, containers meant Docker, Kubernetes, and bash scripts. Not PowerShell and .NET frameworks. But I tried to stay optimistic. After all, how different could it be?
A few days later, I had my answer.
Running Windows inside containers felt a bit like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole. Technically possible, but painful to watch. The tooling was clunky, the builds slow, and debugging often ended with something that looked suspiciously like a “Blue Screen of Container Death”. And the fact that what image you can run depends on the host OS defeats half the purpose of containers to begin with.
By the end of the project, I had learned a lot… mostly patience. There‚Äôs a reason the container ecosystem was built around Linux: it just makes sense. To be fair, this was a few years ago, maybe things have improved since then.
Have you ever had to use Windows containers? What was your experience? Has the ecosystem evolved?

contents:
It happened during a mission for a client. They had decided to move everything to AWS, hoping to scale faster and more easily than with their old bare-metal self-hosted infrastructure.
At first, everything looked perfect. Deployments were smoother, scaling was instant, and everyone was proud of how modern it all felt. The promise of ‚Äúinfinite scalability‚Äù seemed within reach.
But then, the invoices started growing. Each month, the costs climbed higher, and every time the cluster expanded, the bill followed.
It quickly became clear that infinite scalability also meant infinite billing.
After a few years of trying to optimize, the client made a bold decision: they chose to move back to bare metal.
Their reasoning was simple: full control, predictable costs, and no more surprises at the end of the month. And just like that, the loop was complete.
I couldn‚Äôt help but smile when they announced it.
üåç A note on digital sovereignty
Beyond the humor, this story reflects a real trend happening right now in Europe. More and more organizations are considering self-hosting again and not just for cost control, but also to regain digital sovereignty and reduce their dependency on global cloud giants.
The recent AWS outage, which made countless services unreachable, reminded everyone of how fragile this dependency can be. It sparked once again the question of how to balance efficiency, independence, and resilience.
Because while the cloud makes things easy, real sovereignty sometimes means keeping your feet (and your servers) firmly on the ground.
And you, have you experienced the “cloud loop” in your organization? What drove your infrastructure decisions?

contents:
This one goes back to one of my very first missions. I arrived at the client‚Äôs office, full of energy, ready to dive into their development environment.
So I asked the classic first question:
‚ÄúCan I get access to the dev environment?‚Äù
The answer? A USB key. Inside it, a virtual machine image, several gigabytes of it, along with a Word document as the only piece of documentation for the setup. No Git repository, no configuration management, …
That same USB key was being passed from developer to developer like some kind of sacred artifact. When one person made changes to the environment, they‚Äôd just copy it back to the USB and share it again.
When I asked if they used Docker, Ansible, or anything to make the setup reproducible, the client looked at me and said:
‚ÄúWhy bother? We just share the VM around. It‚Äôs reproducible enough, right?‚Äù
At that moment, I knew there was going to be a lot of work ahead. üòÖ
Moral of the story: If your dev environment fits on a USB stick, it‚Äôs not reproducible: it‚Äôs portable chaos…
And you, what’s the most “creative” development setup you’ve encountered in your career?

contents:
Adventures in Uptime is a comic series born from real-life stories I‚Äôve experienced during my years working in IT as a sysadmin and DevOps engineer.
It‚Äôs a humorous take on the sometimes absurd, always unpredictable world of technology, where coffee machines crash, servers live under desks, and ‚Äúeverything is a priority.‚Äù
I wanted to capture those everyday anecdotes we all laugh about later. The kind of moments that every engineer, sysadmin, or office worker has lived at least once. So I decided to turn them into comics.
Each story is told in four panels, short and punchy. Sometimes the comics are purely technical, sometimes they poke fun at office culture, but they all come from real experiences (mine or those shared by colleagues).
I also wanted to explore what‚Äôs possible with AI, using tools like Sora, to generate visuals that bring these moments to life while keeping that clean, expressive comic style I love.
Creating Adventures in Uptime has been a lot of fun! A mix of nostalgia, experimentation, and geek humor. It‚Äôs my way of saying: even when systems crash, coffee spills, and priorities multiply‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs always something to laugh about.
